childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 2004-2016

You were born the year Facebook launched from a Harvard dorm room, which is fitting because social media would shape your entire existence. George W. Bush won re-election that November. The Indian Ocean tsunami killed 230,000 people the day after Christmas. The Boston Red Sox finally broke the Curse of the Bambino after 86 years. Gmail launched with its unthinkable one gigabyte of storage. Your birth year was equally defined by technological optimism and catastrophic loss.

Your childhood was the last gasp of the pre-smartphone era, though you barely remember it. You were three when the first iPhone launched. Four when the App Store opened. You probably don't remember a time before touchscreens, but technically you lived through one. Your parents were still using flip phones when you were born. By the time you started school, they were scrolling through their iPhones while telling you to get off your iPad.

You were four during the 2008 financial crisis. Too young to understand unemployment and foreclosure, old enough to absorb the anxiety in your household. You grew up during the Obama years, which felt stable compared to what came before and after. You were seven when Osama bin Laden was killed. Twelve when marriage equality became law. Your childhood politics were relatively calm, which made adolescence feel like whiplash.

You probably had an iPad before you had a bike. You learned to swipe before you could tie your shoes. Screen time wasn't a controversial parenting topic when you were born—it became one because of your generation. You were the test subjects for what happens when children grow up with infinite digital entertainment. The jury's still out on the results.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen Z

You're Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. Pew Research drew that line, and it stuck. Your generation is roughly 68 million people in the US, making you nearly as large as the Millennials who came before you. By 2030, you'll be the largest generation in the workforce. That's either exciting or terrifying, depending on your employment status.

The defining moment for Gen Z was probably the 2016 election, though it depends who you ask. You were twelve. Old enough to watch the debates, young enough to not vote but feel the consequences. If not 2016, then March 2020—you were fifteen or sixteen when COVID shut everything down. Your sophomore or junior year evaporated into Zoom calls and isolation. The 'best years of your life' became a Netflix binge with a side of existential dread.

Your generation inherited every problem and got blamed for none of them. Climate change, economic inequality, housing crisis, healthcare crisis—all of it was broken before you could vote. You've responded with dark humor, collective organizing, and a complete rejection of the optimism that Millennials were sold and Gen X cynically refused. You're not cynical. You're pragmatic. There's a difference.

Gen Z is the most diverse generation in American history. You're also the most educated, the most socially liberal, and the most likely to identify as LGBTQ+. You've normalized gender fluidity, mental health discussions, and climate activism in ways that make older generations uncomfortable. That discomfort is not your problem.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Mean Girls came out and accidentally created a religion. 'On Wednesdays we wear pink' became a commandment. The Incredibles proved Pixar could make superhero movies better than most superhero movies. Napoleon Dynamite turned awkwardness into an aesthetic that would influence indie culture for a decade. Shrek 2 made more money than the original, which nobody expected.

Musically, 2004 was peak mid-aughts weirdness. Usher's 'Yeah!' dominated everything. Green Day released American Idiot and became politically relevant again. Kanye West dropped The College Dropout and changed hip-hop forever. Modest Mouse somehow got a hit with 'Float On.' The music landscape was diverse in ways that algorithms would eventually destroy.

TV in 2004 launched shows that would become background noise for your childhood. Lost premiered and spent six years confusing everyone. Desperate Housewives brought soapy drama back to primetime. Entourage started making terrible men seem aspirational. House proved that being rude could be a medical qualification.

Your childhood was peak Disney Channel original movies. Your middle school years belonged to Vine, Tumblr, and the Hunger Games. By high school, you were on TikTok before adults discovered it. Your cultural consumption was algorithmic from an early age—you learned to create content before you learned to drive. The parasocial relationship wasn't a new phenomenon; it was just your default mode of engagement.

The pop culture you grew up with was endless, on-demand, and personalized. You've never had to wait a week between episodes. You've never adjusted your schedule around a broadcast. Binging isn't a choice—it's just how content is consumed. This fundamentally changed your relationship with narrative, patience, and shared cultural experiences.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Gmail launched, Google went public, and Facebook started spreading beyond Harvard. The internet in 2004 was Web 2.0—user-generated content, social networking, blogs. MySpace existed. So did Friendster. Neither would survive your childhood.

World of Warcraft launched in 2004, which meant an entire generation of slightly older kids would spend the next decade in Azeroth instead of developing social skills. Mozilla Firefox came out, challenging Internet Explorer's stranglehold on browsing. Flickr launched, pioneering the photo-sharing that Instagram would later perfect and monetize.

You were three when the iPhone launched. You don't remember life before it. You were six when Instagram started, ten when Snapchat appeared, twelve when TikTok's predecessor Musical.ly arrived. You didn't adopt social media—you were raised in it. Your first instinct when something interesting happens is to document it, not experience it.

This makes you the first true digital native generation. Millennials remember the before times. You don't. The internet isn't a tool you use—it's the water you swim in. You've never looked something up in a physical encyclopedia. You've never been truly unreachable. You've never experienced the specific boredom that comes from having nothing to do and no screen to fill the void.

Your relationship with technology isn't complicated—it's symbiotic. You can't remember your friends' phone numbers because your phone remembers for you. You can't navigate without GPS because why would you? You outsource memory, direction, and social connection to devices, which either makes you adaptable or dependent. Probably both.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born the year the Abu Ghraib torture photos surfaced, revealing what the War on Terror actually looked like. You don't remember it, but it set the tone for American foreign policy during your childhood—justified by fear, executed with cruelty, photographed by the perpetrators.

You were four during the 2008 financial crisis. Your parents' anxiety became your baseline. You grew up during the recovery, which for many families meant things never quite returned to normal. You learned early that stability is conditional and prosperity is not guaranteed.

You were six when the Deepwater Horizon oil spill happened. You watched footage of an ocean on fire, which was a decent preview of the environmental disasters that would define your adulthood. Climate change wasn't an abstract future threat—it was birds covered in oil on your TV screen.

You were seven when Osama bin Laden was killed. Your parents probably remember where they were on 9/11. You remember where you were when the mission was announced. The war that started before you were born continued after. It would become the longest war in American history, ending only when you were seventeen.

You were twelve when marriage equality became the law. You were twelve when Michael Brown was killed in Ferguson. You were twelve when the ice bucket challenge briefly made everyone care about ALS. Twelve was a big year.

You were fifteen when COVID-19 shut down the world. Your entire high school experience was disrupted. Proms cancelled, graduations streamed, social development stunted. You spent formative years in isolation, learning to mask (both meanings), and watching adults argue about whether any of it was necessary. You grew up fast, alone, and online.

By the time you could vote at eighteen, you'd already lived through a global pandemic, an attempted insurrection, and the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade. History didn't wait for you to be ready. It never does.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You're entering the workforce now, or about to. The job market is weird—simultaneously hiring and laying off, demanding experience for entry-level positions, offering remote work while calling everyone back to the office. You've been told you're in a 'hot job market' by people who don't understand that most jobs don't pay enough to live on.

Your generation is already being called lazy, entitled, and difficult to manage. This is what every generation says about the next one. Boomers said it about Gen X. Gen X said it about Millennials. Millennials are saying it about you. The pattern is boring. You're not lazy—you're correctly identifying that the deal being offered isn't worth taking.

You watched Millennials hustle themselves into burnout. You saw them sacrifice work-life balance for companies that laid them off via Zoom. You learned that loyalty to employers is a scam. You want fair pay, reasonable hours, and the ability to exist outside of work. This makes you radical, apparently.

The gig economy was normalized before you could work in it. You've never expected a pension. You've never expected employer loyalty. You've never expected that a job would take care of you. This lack of illusion is either depressing or freeing, depending on how you look at it.

Remote work was normalized by the pandemic, which benefits you. You're comfortable with digital collaboration, asynchronous communication, and managing your own time. The downside is that you never learned how to navigate office politics in person, which still matters even when the office is optional. Someone should probably write a guide.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You've never known dating without apps. Tinder launched when you were nine. Bumble when you were eleven. By the time you were old enough to date, swiping was the standard. Meeting someone in person feels almost antiquated, like asking for directions instead of using GPS.

Your generation has less sex, later, with fewer partners than any generation before. This is either a crisis or a correction, depending on who's analyzing it. You're more cautious, more consent-focused, and more likely to identify as somewhere on the asexual spectrum. The pressure to perform sexuality has decreased. Whether intimacy has also decreased is a more complicated question.

You communicate primarily through text, DMs, and snaps. Voice calls feel intrusive. Video calls feel mandatory (thanks, COVID). You've developed entire relationships via message, which your grandparents find incomprehensible. You've also ended relationships via message, which your grandparents find unforgivable.

Your generation is delaying marriage even more than Millennials did—partly economics, partly intentional. You've watched enough divorces to be cautious about commitment. You've also seen enough healthy relationships modeled online to know what you want. The bar is simultaneously lower (functional communication) and higher (emotional intelligence, shared values, TikTok-compatible lifestyle).

Friendship looks different for you. Your closest friends might live in different countries, connected through Discord servers and group chats. You maintain relationships asynchronously, across time zones, through shared media and memes. Physical proximity is optional. Emotional proximity is everything.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were four during the 2008 financial crisis. Your first conscious memories of money involve anxiety. You grew up watching your parents stress about mortgages, layoffs, and the price of everything. Economic insecurity isn't something you learned—it's something you absorbed through the walls of your childhood home.

Your relationship with money is defined by having watched everything break before you could participate. Housing prices tripled during your childhood. Tuition quadrupled. Wages stayed flat. By the time you're old enough to buy a house, the average price will be nine times the median income. Your grandparents bought houses at three times their income. Math has abandoned you.

You're more likely than Millennials to save aggressively, invest early, and treat financial literacy as survival training rather than optional enrichment. You've watched too many TikToks about compound interest to ignore it. You've also watched too many TikToks about the housing market to believe you'll ever afford a home. The cognitive dissonance is exhausting.

Student loans are a reality you're facing or will face soon. The debt-to-income ratio for your generation is unprecedented. You're starting your financial life in a hole that previous generations didn't have to climb out of. Every financial milestone—car, apartment, marriage, kids—requires more money than it did for your parents, adjusted for inflation.

Your generation has embraced side hustles not as liberation but as necessity. You've been monetizing hobbies since you were old enough to have them. Content creation isn't a dream—it's a backup plan. The line between work and life dissolved before you entered either. You don't expect to retire. You expect to work until you physically can't, and you're planning accordingly.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest weakness is the same as its biggest strength: you're chronically online. You've developed sophisticated media literacy, but you've also developed the attention span of a goldfish with ADHD. Long-form content feels like work. Nuance gets lost in character limits. You can identify misinformation faster than any generation, but you also get your news from TikToks that may or may not be accurate.

You're so comfortable with digital communication that you've potentially underdeveloped in-person social skills. The pandemic didn't help. You missed crucial years of learning to read rooms, navigate awkward silences, and exist without a screen to retreat to. This will matter in job interviews, dates, and any situation where you can't edit your response before sending.

Your generation has normalized mental health discussion, which is good. You've also potentially over-pathologized normal human experiences. Sadness becomes depression. Nervousness becomes anxiety. Personality quirks become disorders. The vocabulary is helpful for those who need it and potentially limiting for those who don't. Not every struggle requires a diagnosis.

You're so aware of systemic problems that individual action can feel pointless. Why recycle when corporations produce most emissions? Why vote when the system is rigged? The macro view is correct, but the micro view matters too. Nihilism dressed as political awareness is still nihilism. Giving up feels rational but isn't actually a strategy.

Your generation is fluent in irony to the point where sincerity feels risky. Everything is a bit, a meme, a reference. Earnestness is cringe. This protects you from vulnerability but also prevents depth. At some point, you'll need to care about things without a layer of protective irony. It's harder than it sounds.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2024-2034): You're in this decade now, or just entering it. The job market is chaotic. Housing is impossible. You're probably living with roommates or parents longer than you expected. This is the decade where you're supposed to 'figure things out,' but nobody told you what that actually means. You'll likely change jobs multiple times, not out of flakiness but out of necessity and opportunity. Your twenties will be defined by adaptation, not stability. Get comfortable with uncertainty—it's not going away.

Your 30s (2034-2044): By now, you'll have survived your first full decade in the workforce. You'll probably be making more money, though it still won't feel like enough. Housing might become possible, though not in the city you actually want to live in. This is traditionally when people 'settle down,' but your generation is redefining what settlement means. Maybe it's homeownership. Maybe it's a van. Maybe it's a co-living arrangement that older generations find baffling. You'll have more clarity about who you are and less patience for pretending otherwise.

Your 40s (2044-2054): This will be your peak earning decade, statistically, though statistics don't capture individual reality. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live, which industries exist, what 'normal' looks like. You'll be managing aging parents, potentially your own kids, and a career that's probably transformed multiple times. The skills you learned in your twenties will be obsolete; your ability to learn new skills will be your most valuable asset. You'll be old enough to be nostalgic for the 2020s, which is a strange thought.

Your 50s (2054-2064): Fifty years from your birth. The world will be unrecognizable. You'll have lived through climate adaptation (or climate catastrophe), AI transformation of the economy, and whatever geopolitical shifts happen between now and then. Retirement at 65 probably won't exist the way it did for previous generations. You'll be working in some capacity, whether by choice or necessity. You'll be explaining to younger people what the world was like before—before what, you don't know yet. That's the strange part of forecasting. The biggest changes haven't happened yet.

Your 60s and beyond (2064+): If current trends hold, you'll live into your 80s or 90s. Medical technology might extend that further. You'll need financial resources for a longer retirement than any generation before, earned from a more unstable career, in a more expensive world. The math doesn't math, as your generation would say. But generations have survived impossible math before. Adaptation is the human superpower. You've already proven you can adapt to unprecedented circumstances. You'll do it again.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4.1 million people born in 2004. The entire Gen Z generation is about 68 million people in the US, making it nearly as large as Millennials and poised to become the dominant generation in the workforce by 2030.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more pragmatic and less optimistic. Millennials believed the system could be fixed. You've never believed the system worked in the first place. They remember the before times; you don't. They adapted to smartphones; you were raised by them. They have student loan debt; you watched them drown in it and are trying to make different choices, though the math isn't easier.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you share a certain skepticism, but from different sources. Gen X was cynical because they were ignored—the forgotten middle child of generations. You're pragmatic because you've been watched and analyzed since birth. Gen X had MTV. You have TikTok. Different mediums, similar sense that adults don't understand you. They're right that adults don't understand you.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the differences are so vast they barely register as the same species occupying the same economy. Boomers bought houses for two years' salary. You'll be lucky to buy a house at ten years' salary. Boomers had pensions, job security, and affordable education. You have gig work, at-will employment, and crushing student debt. They controlled 21% of the nation's wealth at your age. You control about 1%. The numbers are not typos.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), you're practically Luddites. They've had tablets since infancy. They've been documented on social media since birth. They're being raised by AI in ways that haven't fully manifested yet. You at least remember a childhood with some analog elements. They won't. Whether that matters, only time will tell.

Your life expectancy is projected at 77-79 years, slightly lower than Millennials due to rising 'deaths of despair' and the health effects of chronic stress, sedentary lifestyle, and climate change. Your generation has higher rates of anxiety and depression than any before—though that might be better detection and reduced stigma rather than actual increase. Either way, you're more medicated, more therapized, and more aware of your mental health than any previous generation. That awareness is both your burden and your potential salvation.

year_events: Facebook launched from a Harvard dorm room
Boston Red Sox broke the Curse of the Bambino
Gmail launched with one gigabyte of storage
